author: @sobinsunny3974
text: Successful and thanks a lot. I had a lot of issues in live streaming with my pi. Firstly, VLC was not getting installed in my pi. I browsed over different forums and watched lot of videos but problem did not resolve. I tried with one of my other rpi and vlc got installed easily with these: sudo apt-get update sudo apt-get install vlc  So, if you face the same problem, just remove your SD card and format it using any SD card formatter software. Then copy and paste extracted NOOBS file into the SD card. Now, insert the SD card into the rpi and install rasbian OS all new. This might resolve all the problems with VLC or any other package installation.  Secondly, live streaming to another device was unable. I downloaded VLC in my android smartphone. Open VLC and in Open MRL option type http://yourIPaddress:8160. Also, Open VLC media player in windows laptop or desktop and click File - Network stream - HTTP - http://yourIPaddress:8160 and click OK.  This will give your live streaming to that device very sooner if your internet is good enough.  IMPORTANT: Your RPi, Smartphone as well as Windows must be connected to same IP ie.,WiFi or wlan  NB: If you don't know your IP address, open terminal in RPi and type ifconfig. You will see your IP address in inet.

author: @mattrupert
text: Hi Harrison, In your video here on getting the Pi camera to stream you have the long command line "raspivid -o - -t 0 -hf -w 800 -h 400 -fps 24 |cvlc -vvv stream:///dev/stdin --sout '#standard{access=http,mux=ts,dst=:8­160}' :demux=h264"  I did this and got it to work for the most part.  Im seeing all kind of warnings and buffering going on from the text window output.  Im wondering if the Pi2b that I have is not able to keep up computationally with the requirements to convert the video into a h264 stream.  I think I knocked the resolution down to 320x200.  Does the command line you have there take advantage and use the hardware h264 encoder that is onboard the pi2?  At least from what I have read in the specs there is a hardware encoder.  Thanks for your video!! Matt
